title: 113_hr4496
content: The Act is titled the "Covering People With Pre-Existing Conditions Act of 2014" and establishes universal access programs to improve high-risk pools and reinsurance markets for individuals with pre-existing conditions. Each State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments not used on State health care programs. Each State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments not used on State health care programs. States without a qualified high-risk pool must establish a State reinsurance program to meet this requirement. The State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments. If a State is already operating a qualified high-risk pool, it shall not be treated as a qualified high-risk pool as of January 1, 2015. As of January 1, 2015, a State operating a current qualified high-risk pool must transition to a qualified State reinsurance program using premium assessment funds. The State may use premium assessment funds to transition from operating a high-risk pool to a qualified State reinsurance program if the pool is in strong fiscal health. A qualified State reinsurance program is defined as a program for this purpose. A qualified State reinsurance program, as defined by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners and approved by the State Insurance Commissioner, provides reinsurance for health insurance coverage in the small group market. It can operate on a prospective or retrospective basis to protect health insurance issuers against annual aggregate spending. A qualified State reinsurance program can provide reinsurance on a prospective or retrospective basis, protecting health insurance issuers against annual aggregate spending and catastrophic costs. It is deemed a qualified high-risk pool under section 2745 of the Public Health Service Act. A qualifying State high-risk pool must meet specific requirements. A qualifying State high-risk pool under section 2745 of the Public Health Service Act must offer two coverage options, including a high deductible health plan with a health savings account. It should have stable funding, no waiting lists, and cover all eligible residents seeking coverage. The high-risk pool must eliminate waiting lists, cover individuals in the disability waiting period for Medicare eligibility, limit premiums to 150% of the average, and conduct education and outreach initiatives for eligible residents. The high-risk pool must provide coverage for preventive services, disease management for chronic diseases, and verify citizenship or alien qualification for eligibility. The provision of law states that only US citizens and nationals can participate in a State high-risk pool receiving funds under the Public Health Service Act. States must certify that applicants provide documentation of citizenship or nationality. The Secretary must maintain records for citizenship verification. The provision requires US citizens and nationals in State high-risk pools to provide documentation of citizenship. The Secretary must keep records for citizenship verification. Waivers may be granted for innovative programs. The pool must meet specific criteria to qualify as a high-risk pool under the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary has the authority to waive requirements for state reinsurance programs and high-risk pools. Funding of $15 billion for 2015-2024 and an additional $10 billion for 2020-2024 is allocated for this purpose. Definitions for health insurance coverage and issuer are provided in this section. The Act allocates $15 billion for 2015-2024 and an additional $10 billion for 2020-2024 for high-risk pools meeting specific criteria under the Public Health Service Act. Definitions for health insurance coverage and issuer are included in the section. The term "current section 2745 qualified high risk pool" refers to the definition of "qualified high risk pool" under section 2745(g) of the Public Health Service Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The term "standard risk rate" is a rate determined under the State high risk pool based on premium rates, actuarial techniques, and anticipated claims experience and expenses. The term "State" refers to any of the 50 States or the District of Columbia. It involves insurance issuers offering health coverage using actuarial techniques and reflecting anticipated claims experience and expenses.
